question: Overuse of pesticides and fertilizers can result in what environmental issue?

content.source_1: When nitrogen and phosphorus fertilizers are applied in amounts exceeding crop uptake, surplus nitrate leaches to groundwater and N/P run off to surface waters, which are major drivers of eutrophication and harmful algal blooms.
content.source_2: Overuse of pesticides increases residue levels in agricultural runoff and nearby streams; monitoring frequently detects multiple pesticides in surface waters draining farmed landscapes at ecologically relevant concentrations.
content.source_3: Vegetated riparian buffers and filter strips intercept field runoff, trapping sediments and attached phosphorus; syntheses report they can remove a large fraction of sediment and associated nutrients before water reaches streams.
content.source_4: Edge-of-field denitrifying bioreactors and constructed wetlands treat tile drainage and runoff, often removing a substantial portion of nitrate loads prior to discharge into receiving waters.
content.source_5: Many commonly used modern pesticides (e.g., synthetic pyrethroids) are hydrophobic, strongly adsorb to soil, and degrade within days to weeks via photolysis and microbial activity, limiting off-site movement when erosion is controlled.
content.source_6: Conservation practices such as no-till and cover crops dramatically reduce soil erosion, which in turn reduces transport of phosphorus and soil-bound pesticides off fields.
